awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Spectroscopy at Coe College
awd_abstract_narration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site at Coe College provides eight undergraduate students each summer the opportunity to participate in research on topics in optics, glass science, acoustics, molecular biology, detector physics, modeling, and biomaterials, all under the common focus of spectroscopy. In addition to participating in research with an experienced and dedicated mentor, the REU students will engage in activities such as seminars and lectures and give two oral presentations, one at mid-term and then a final twenty minute talk. 

This project includes a Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) site, where each summer two high school teachers from nearby school districts participate in a research project. During the academic year, the teachers are invited to bring their students to Coe College to learn about the work they carried out. The teachers will use their experience to motivate their students to better understand the physical world and prepare them to become the future generation of scientists. 

The participants will be exposed and trained in a variety of techniques and equipment, including Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), Raman spectroscopy, Nuclear Magnetic Resonance, Scanning Electron Microscope, absorption and fluorescence spectroscopies, x-ray fluorescence, calorimetry, and others. The projects are designed to be suitable for undergraduates, but also challenging and leading to results of interest to external researchers.

por.por_cntn:
The REU site at Coe College hosted 21 undergraduate students and four high school teachers engaged in various areas of scientific research.  The students could witness the entire scientific process by spanning glass science, optics, acoustics, astrophysics, molecular biology, biochemistry, detector development, and environmental science.  The research work pans the physics, chemistry, and biology departments, involving (over the life of the grant) eight faculty members.  From making samples to using spectroscopy as a tool for analysis, the REU participants carried out high-level science and reported their results at their home institutions and regional and national meetings.  The holistic activities of the site--which included career panels, scientific curriculum vitae writing, company visits, and speakers--gave students a well-rounded view of the field. The work carried out by the REU students prepared them for a future career in science--and perhaps graduate work after they finish college.  The faculty members will continue their work as mentors even beyond the time spent at the REU site.

The teachers were able to conduct research and use their experiences to bring back ideas and experiments to their classrooms.  The faculty members supervising the research work were also available for brainstorming possible high school activities. 

The country benefitted from the formation of a cadre of highly trained young scientists with skills in spectroscopy.  These skills are relevant to scientific research and also for applications in homeland security and defense.

Finally, we note that the COVID pandemic was  unable to stop the work of the REU site, which managed five remote projects (involving modeling, simulation, and theoretical work) during the summer of 2020.  This provided rare opportunities during a challenging time, and enabled young students to continue their scientific education.
